name: tubular-bells
definition: The orchestral instrument consisting of a row of vertically suspended metal tubes struck with a mallet.
description:
Tubular bells are musical instruments in the percussion family.

Their sound resembles that of church bells, carillon, or a bell tower; the original tubular bells were made to duplicate the sound of church bells within an ensemble.

Each bell is a metal tube, 30–38 mm in diameter, tuned by altering its length.

Tubular bells are sometimes struck on the top edge of the tube with a rawhide- or plastic-headed hammer.

Studio chimes are similar in appearance to tubular bells, but each bell has a smaller diameter than the corresponding bell on tubular bells.

As orchestral chimes, tubular bells can attain greater rhythmic precision than true bells, and their tone is clearer, for it emphasizes fewer higher harmonics.

Chimes are often used in concert band pieces. It rarely plays melody, instead being used most often as a color to add to the ensemble sound.

featured.caption: Tubular bells are often replaced by studio chimes, which are smaller and usually less expensive instruments.

facts.name: Sustain pedal for extended ringing
facts.value: Often, a sustain pedal will be attached to allow extended ringing of the bells. They can also be bowed at the bottom of the tube to produce a very loud, very high-pitched overtone.

facts.name: Used on grandfather clock
facts.value: Tubular bells are also used in longcase clocks, particularly because they produce a louder sound than gongs and regular chime-rods and therefore could be heard more easily.

facts.name: The tubes provide a purer tone
facts.value: The tubes used provide a purer tone than solid cylindrical chimes, such as those on a mark tree.

facts.name: First used by Verdi in 'Il trovatore'
facts.value: Tubular bells as a substitute for church bells were first used by Giuseppe Verdi in his operas Il trovatore (1853) and Un ballo in maschera (1859).

facts.name: Initially used to replace church bells
facts.value: Large tubular bells were at first used as a substitute for church bells in towers.

facts.name: Incorporated into theater organs
facts.value: In the early XX-th century tubular bells were also incorporated into theater organs to produce effects.

facts.name: In England from 1886
facts.value: They first appeared in England in an 1886 performance of Arthur Sullivan’s Golden Legend in Coventry.

facts.name: Mike Oldfield
facts.value: Multi-instrumentalist Mike Oldfield has used tubular bells on many of his studio albums, most notably Tubular Bells (1973), Tubular Bells II (1992) and Tubular Bells III (1998).

facts.name: Later was introduced in orchestras
facts.value: Smaller tubes were later built to be controlled from an organ manual or, in the orchestra, to be played directly by a percussionist.
